RT @SenateAgGOP Roberts: I am confident that the Committee will once again work in a bipartisan fashion to ensure that our U.S. grain system continues to facilitate reliable U.S. grain exports for years to come. This hearing is the first step in this process.

RT @SenateAgGOP Roberts: I also look forward to hearing from our witnesses regarding their experiences with the Federal Grain Inspection Service since it has been realigned under the Agricultural Marketing Service.

RT @SenateAgGOP Roberts: Today‚Äôs hearing gives us a chance to hear directly from stakeholders on what is working well and where we might consider making improvements to the U.S. Grain Standards Act.
RT @SenateAgGOP Roberts: The witnesses we will hear from represent different perspectives in the grain and oilseed value chain‚Äîa farmer, an inspector, a grain handler, and an exporter.

RT @SenateAgGOP Roberts: A provision in the 2018 #FarmBill allowed for a restoration of the previous exceptions. This serves as a reminder of the careful consideration we must take during the upcoming reauthorization to avoid unintended consequences.

RT @SenateAgGOP Roberts: Most of the 2015 reauthorization has been implemented. However, Congress did not intend for the Federal Grain Inspection Service to allow for the unilateral cancellation of many of the existing exceptions to the geographical boundaries for domestic inspections
RT @SenateAgGOP Roberts: Transparency is also an important step to continue certainty and predictability in the grain inspection and weighing system.

RT @SenateAgGOP Roberts: After disruptions of export inspections in 2014, the Grain Standards Act was further modified to require the Secretary of Agriculture to take immediate action to maintain export inspections and to provide daily updates to Congress.

RT @SenateAgGOP Roberts: In the 1970s, after irregularities in grain inspection and weighing led to grand jury investigations and indictments, there were major reforms to the Grain Standards Act to ensure the reliability and quality of U.S. grains and oilseeds.

RT @NBCLatino In Detroit, ‚Å¶@JulianCastro‚Å© aims to build on the success of his first debate: ‚ÄúWhat he showed people is he can go toe-to-toe with Trump and he has a strong vision for the future,‚Äù said campaign manager ‚Å¶@MayaRupert‚Å© , by ‚Å¶@SuzGamboa‚Å©  https://www.nbcnews.com/news/latino/detroit-juli-n-castro-aims-build-success-first-debate-n1036451

RT @SenateAgGOP Roberts: For over 100 years, the U.S. Grain Standards Act has authorized USDA to establish marketing standards for grains and oilseeds. These official standards, set by regulations, define each grain, each class of grain & the numerical grades of specific physical characteristics

RT @SenateAgGOP Roberts: Maintaining the certainty and predictability of the grain inspection and weighing system is key for the successful flow of grain and oilseeds‚Äîfrom their origin at farms across the country to their eventual destinations, including critical export markets.
RT @SenateAgGOP Roberts: The members of this Committee know that the farm economy and global grain trade face unique challenges.

RT @SenateAgGOP Roberts: Today, we will examine the importance of the U.S. grain inspection system, hear directly from key stakeholders, and discuss provisions in the Grain Standards Act that will expire on September 30, 2020 without Congressional action.
RT @SenateAgGOP Roberts: This hearing on reauthorization of the U.S. Grain Standards Act is an important step in continuing the Committee‚Äôs work to reauthorize programs in our jurisdiction.

Ranking Member @SenStabenow begins her opening statement at the #SenateAg hearing on the reauthorization of the U.S. Grain Standards Act. Watch LIVE: http://ag.senate.gov

Roberts: A provision in the 2018 #FarmBill allowed for a restoration of the previous exceptions. This serves as a reminder of the careful consideration we must take during the upcoming reauthorization to avoid unintended consequences.

Roberts: Most of the 2015 reauthorization has been implemented. However, Congress did not intend for the Federal Grain Inspection Service to allow for the unilateral cancellation of many of the existing exceptions to the geographical boundaries for domestic inspections
Roberts: Transparency is also an important step to continue certainty and predictability in the grain inspection and weighing system.

Roberts: After disruptions of export inspections in 2014, the Grain Standards Act was further modified to require the Secretary of Agriculture to take immediate action to maintain export inspections and to provide daily updates to Congress.

Roberts: In the 1970s, after irregularities in grain inspection and weighing led to grand jury investigations and indictments, there were major reforms to the Grain Standards Act to ensure the reliability and quality of U.S. grains and oilseeds.

Roberts: For over 100 years, the U.S. Grain Standards Act has authorized USDA to establish marketing standards for grains and oilseeds. These official standards, set by regulations, define each grain, each class of grain & the numerical grades of specific physical characteristics

Roberts: Maintaining the certainty and predictability of the grain inspection and weighing system is key for the successful flow of grain and oilseeds‚Äîfrom their origin at farms across the country to their eventual destinations, including critical export markets.
Roberts: The members of this Committee know that the farm economy and global grain trade face unique challenges.

Roberts: Today, we will examine the importance of the U.S. grain inspection system, hear directly from key stakeholders, and discuss provisions in the Grain Standards Act that will expire on September 30, 2020 without Congressional action.

An important note for people talking about the federal budget:

Spending bills are valued over a one-year period. Tax bills are valued over a 10-year period.

In other words, a $1.3T spending bill is 10x larger than a $1.3T tax bill. The spending bill has 10x the deficit impact.
